Author: Michael Stapelberg
Comment: Why would you ever want to do that for storage? I am not aware of _any_ place where, even though it says gigabyte, actual gigabytes are displayed. Everybody means gibibytes.

Author: Mats
Comment:
Personally, I find powers of 1000 easier to work with than powers of 1024 :)

But that’s not really the reason why I submitted this patch. It’s more about the unambiguity that comes along with using the standardized prefixes¹, especially the binary ones. There are numerous programs that adopted this form, e.g., pacman, gdisk, aria2c, …

But there’s also software that uses the SI prefixes with their actual decimal meaning: apt-get, dd, fdisk, and most prominently OS X throughout the entire system².

¹ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEC_80000-13
² https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_prefix#Current_practice

Author: Michael Stapelberg
Comment:
I’m all in for unambiguity, but not in the way you proposed.

I’d accept a patch that changes the output from GB to GiB to reflect what is actually happening, with an option to force GB for people who want the wrong suffix :).
